channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Stampeding Turtles Might Have Made Fossil Tracks in Italian Cliffs
item.description: Researchers suggest that an earthquake spooked a mob of sea turtles gathered together in a prehistoric sea.
item.dc:creator: Carolyn Wilke

item.title: His Group Made World-Class Measurements of Atomic Elements
item.description: Yuri Ralchenko led one of the oldest teams at the National Institute for Standards and Technology. The fate of some experiments hangs in the air.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.category: National Institute of Standards and Technology
item.media:credit: Moriah Ratner for The New York Times

item.title: When a Murder Hornet Becomes a Tasty Meal
item.description: A researcher found that a Japanese pond frog is impervious to the stings of the northern giant hornet, even when it goes down the hatch.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: Sterile Neutrino Prediction Muddled by Latest Experiments
item.description: Two papers challenged the existence of theorized particles called sterile neutrinos that might account for mysteries like the cosmos’s dark matter.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: Workers installing the MicroBooNE time-projection chamber into the experiment’s cryostat at Fermilab in 2013.

item.title: Trump’s NASA Pick Poised to Win Senate Vote After Do-Over Hearing
item.description: The president withdrew Jared Isaacman’s nomination to lead the space agency in June, but senators of both parties appeared willing to give him a second shot at confirmation.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.category: Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Isaacman, the billionaire entrepreneur and NASA administrator nominee, appearing before the Senate on Wednesday.

item.title: Could Weight Loss Drugs Turn Fat Cats Into Svelte Ozempets?
item.description: GLP-1 drugs for pets could be the next frontier for the blockbuster weight loss and diabetes drugs.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: Recent estimates suggest that roughly 60 percent of the nation’s cats and dogs are obese, and hundreds of thousands of cats and dogs have diabetes.

item.title: Sharks and Rays Gain Sweeping Protections from Wildlife Trade
item.description: A global treaty has extended trade protections to more than 70 shark and ray species whose numbers are in sharp decline.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times

item.title: It’s No Dodo, But This Newly Discovered Bird Could Share the Same Fate
item.description: The slaty-masked tinamou, recently discovered in Brazil, is utterly unafraid of people. That could be its undoing, ornithologists worry.
item.dc:creator: Joe Trezza

item.title: Russian Launch Site Mishap Leaves Country’s Space Program in Limbo
item.description: The ability of Russia to launch astronauts to the International Space Station remains in limbo after an incident last week at the Baikonur base in Kazakhstan.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A Soyuz spacecraft launching from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on Nov. 27. The rocket itself headed to space without problem, but the rocket’s exhaust knocked a service platform out of its protective shelter.

item.title: The Married Scientists Torn Apart by a Covid Bioweapon Theory
item.description: In 2020, a Chinese virologist fled to the United States, aided by allies of President Trump who sought to promote her unproven theories about the origins of Covid-19. Her husband still can’t find her.
item.dc:creator: Katie J.M. Baker
item.media:description: Dr. Li-Meng Yan spoke in 2021 at a summit in Anchorage, Alaska, on early outpatient treatment for the Covid-19 virus.

item.title: California Discourages Wild Mushroom Foraging After Fatal Outbreak
item.description: Officials said one person was killed and 20 others were poisoned after eating death cap mushrooms, which look and taste like safe mushrooms but can cause liver failure.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: California Department of Health, via Associated Press
item.media:description: California health officials advised people to stop foraging for wild mushrooms after a poison found in one variety killed one person and caused liver damage to others.

item.title: Could President Trump Bring Japan’s Tiny Cars to America? Not So Fast.
item.description: Mr. Trump is pushing to approve their production in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: A Japanese kei-car sits in a garage in Sapporo, Japan.

item.title: Kidney Recipient Dies After Transplant From Organ Donor Who Had Rabies
item.description: Only four donors have transmitted rabies to organ transplant recipients since 1978, according to federal officials.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A man died of rabies he contracted after receiving a kidney transplant from another person who later tested positive for the virus after being scratched by a skunk.

item.title: Scientists Are Measuring Ocean Currents in Hopes of Charting AMOC’s Future
item.description: Scientists fear warming is driving a collapse in the ocean currents that shape climate far and wide. The ice-choked waters off Greenland might hold the key.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Esther Horvath
item.media:description: Scoresby Sound, a fjord in eastern Greenland, as seen from the research ship.

item.title: Hamilton O. Smith, Who Made a Biotech Breakthrough, Is Dead at 94
item.description: A Nobel laureate, he identified an enzyme that cuts DNA, laying the groundwork for milestones in scientific research and medicine, like insulin.
item.dc:creator: Delthia Ricks
item.media:credit: Marty Katz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamilton Smith in 2000. His work essentially handed scientists the power to isolate, analyze and manually move discrete sequences of DNA.

item.title: A Look at What Lives Where Deep Sea Mining Would Happen
item.description: An ocean-mining company has funded some of the most comprehensive scientific studies to date, and peer-reviewed results have begun to emerge.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

item.title: MAHA Activists Urge Trump to Fire Lee Zeldin at the E.P.A.
item.description: As head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Lee Zeldin has weakened protections against toxic chemicals, say members of the MAHA movement.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A petition to fire Lee Zeldin, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, had more than 2,800 signatures by midday Friday.

item.title: Climate Shift Upends Atlantic Seaweed: One Massive Patch Grows as Another Vanishes
item.description: Blooms of yellowish-brown seaweed along the Equator are breaking records and defiling beaches, while a centuries-old patch farther north is disappearing.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: Mexican National Guard members during a sargassum seaweed cleanup event in Cancun, Mexico, in June.

item.title: Inside RFK Jr.’s Methodical Quest to Shake Up America’s Vaccine System
item.description: The health secretary has walled himself off from government scientists and empowered fellow activists to pursue his vaccine agenda.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, conferring with Hannah Anderson, then one of his top advisers, during a hearing in May.

item.title: Trump Returns to Gasoline as Fuel of Choice for Cars, Gutting Biden’s Climate Policy
item.description: The president said he would weaken Biden-era mileage standards, which were designed to increase electric-vehicle sales, calling them a “scam.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Maxine Joselow and Jack Ewing
item.media:description: President Trump, surrounded by executives from the auto industry, in the Oval Office on Wednesday.

item.title: What Is ‘Masking,’ and Is It Harmful?
item.description: “Masking” is part of life, especially for those with autism or A.D.H.D. But hiding your true self comes with a cost.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Environmentally Friendly Coffee
item.description: Here’s what to know about your daily brew and the environment.
item.dc:creator: Kate Selig
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Shutterstock

item.title: Trump Expected to Significantly Weaken Fuel Economy Rules
item.description: Executives from top automakers were invited to attend the announcement at the White House on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:description: The Biden-era auto emissions rules have significantly reduced the planet-warming greenhouse gases from transportation, which is the single largest source of carbon pollution in the United States.

item.title: Solving the Home Care Quandary
item.description: Paid home care is buckling under the surging demands of an aging population. But there are alternatives that could upgrade jobs and improve patient care.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span

item.title: After Trump’s MRI Claim, His Doctor’s Memo Offers Little Clarity
item.description: While the president said he had an M.R.I. exam, a physician’s memo released by the White House was less specific.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The statement, by Dr. Sean P. Barbabella, said the tests on President Trump’s cardiovascular system and abdominal region showed the president “remains in excellent overall health.”

item.title: FEMA Won’t Reinstate Suspended Workers Who Signed Letter Criticizing Trump
item.description: Employees suspended in the summer after signing a letter critical of the president were told they could return to work. But the reinstatement was short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A FEMA search and rescue worker in Swannanoa, N.C., after Hurricane Helene last year.

item.title: Inside the Bird-Flu Vaccine Trial for Monk Seals
item.description: After the virus returned to Hawaii this fall, testing the shots in the endangered seal species became urgent.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Loren Elliott
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
